headline: Hyundai Motor: The Cost of Sentimentality
summary: Hyundai Motor's bid for 35% of Hyundai Engineering & Construction looks like a sentimental effort to revive the old Hyundai empire. Shareholders deserve a better explanation of the business case for the potential deal.

headline: Howdy, Partner
summary: Read eight stories of how entrepreneurial pairs met.

headline: Competitive Growth
summary: None

headline: Attorney in Probe of Stevens Case Commits Suicide
summary: A federal prosecutor who was among those being investigated over the Justice Department's troubled pursuit of the late Alaska Sen. Ted Stevens committed suicide over the weekend.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Sept. 28
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Sept. 28

headline: Morgan Stanley Freezes Some Hiring
summary: The move includes investment-banking and sales-and-trading operations, but not the wealth-management business.

headline: Dow Pulls Back; Banks Fall
summary: The Dow industrials closed down 48.22 points, or 0.44%, at 10812.04 as investors sold financial stocks.

headline: Obama Advocates Education Changes
summary: Obama said he would like to extend the school year and raise teacher pay to help improve the education system.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: AirTran Holdings, NightHawk Radiology Holdings: Biggest Price Gainers (AAI, NHWK)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 27
summary: In today's pictures, Chavez supporters receive word on Venezuela election results, a child sleeps on the street in Manila, a man walks in a fog in Iowa and more.

headline: Rural Buying May Lift India Gold Demand
summary: Gold investments in India are likely to pick up starting in November as the harvest of an expected bumper summer-season crop puts more money in the hands of farmers, who traditionally stash away their savings in precious metals.

headline: Astra's Cancer Drug Fails Trial
summary: AstraZeneca suffered a fresh setback with news its experimental prostate-cancer pill Zibotentan failed in a late clinical trial to significantly improve overall survival.

headline: Energy Fund Passes Oil-Spill Test
summary: Ten percent of the companies held by the Guinness Atkinson Global Energy Fund were directly involved in the Deepwater Horizon disaster. The fund's investing philosophy helped limit its downside exposure.

headline: Treasurys Climb After Strong Auction
summary: The U.S. sold $36 billion in two-year notes at a record low yield of 0.441%, and Treasurys rallied as investors continued to fret about the health of the global economy and stocked up on low-risk assets.

headline: Oil Prices Take a Pause, End at $78.57
summary: Crude futures were mostly flat Monday, pausing after Friday's rally to settle at $78.57 a barrel.

headline: Henderson Land Official Studies TVB Stake
summary: The elder son of Hong Kong businessman Lee Shau-kee, is studying the possibility of buying a stake in broadcaster TVB.

headline: U.S. Stocks on Clear Path Up
summary: Even as the September stock-market run-up has hit historic proportions, technicians still believe this rally has the potential for additional gains.

headline: Wolseley Moves Tax Residence to Switzerland
summary: Building-materials company Wolseley is becoming the latest U.K. company to move its residence abroad to cut its tax burden, after reporting narrowing full-year losses and announcing its intention to resume dividend payments.

headline: AIG Must Defend Shareholder Suit
summary: AIG must defend a shareholder lawsuit that alleged the insurer made misstatements about its exposure to the subprime mortgage market, a federal judge ruled.

headline: Hearing Set on Potash Move to Block BHP Bid
summary: A federal court hearing is scheduled for Nov. 4 on Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan's motion for an injunction to block BHP Billiton's hostile offer for the Canadian fertilizer company.

headline: European Markets Fall Back
summary: Stocks in Europe finished lower as fresh worries over the region's banking system overshadowed the day's relatively upbeat corporate news.

headline: Building U2's Claw
summary: Mark Fisher designs stage sets for music's elite, and his portfolio traces the evolution of the rock concert spectacle. Here, the initial sketches and final results of his concept for U2's world tour, U2 360°, which became known as "The Claw."

headline: China Air to Plead Guilty to Price Fixing
summary: China Airlines has agreed to plead guilty to fixing prices on air-cargo shipments and will pay a $40 million criminal fine, the U.S. Justice said.

headline: Bank Worries Hit European Shares
summary: European stock markets declined Monday on fresh worries over the region's banking system after a downgrade of Allied Irish Bank debt. Tokyo led Asian markets higher.

headline: FSB Warns on Financial System's Vulnerability
summary: The FSB said the global financial system remains vulnerable because of continuing fiscal tensions in developed economies and fragile banks.

headline: Regulators Target Annuity Bets
summary: A group of state insurance regulators proposed measures for insurers to guard against sales of retirement products driven by professional investors as market bets.

headline: Officials Testify on Oil Spill
summary: A panel appointed by President Barack Obama to investigate the BP oil spill heard testimony from the federal official running the spill response and others Monday.

headline: The Genius of the Tinkerer
summary: Author Steven Johnson argues that ideas are works of bricolage. "We take the ideas we've inherited or stumbled across, and we jigger them together into some new shape." Two sets of artists, nerdbots and Ann P. Smith, take a similar approach to their sculptures, made from found objects.

headline: Lymphoma Drug Shows Success
summary: Seattle Genetics Inc. said its novel blood cancer treatment, which attacks cancerous cells but ignores healthy ones, shrank tumors in three-quarters of patients with Hodgkin lymphoma, according to a study released Monday.

headline: AirTran Holdings, NightHawk Radiology Holdings: Biggest Price Gainers (AAI, NHWK)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Zale Loss Narrows
summary: Zale posted a sharply narrower loss for its fiscal fourth quarter. The struggling jeweler was helped by a sharp reduction in write-downs and a surge in margins but sales continued to weaken.

headline: Japan Plans Stimulus
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan told his cabinet to begin work on a supplementary budget designed to boost the faltering economy; meanwhile, Japan reported exports were up 15.8% in August from a year earlier, down from July's 23.5% pace.

headline: CME Fines Vice Chairman's Firm
summary: CME Group disciplined a proprietary trading firm co-headed by the exchange operator's vice chairman for alleged trading activity carried out by his brother.

headline: Conn. Attorney General Probes GMAC Mortgage
summary: Connecticut's attorney general is probing GMAC Mortgage over what he claims are "defective foreclosure documents" filed in Connecticut.

headline: Exxon's Sakhalin-1 to Start Production
summary: The Sakhalin-1 consortium operated by Exxon Mobil will launch commercial production at a new oil field off Russia's Pacific coast this week at a ceremony attended by President Dmitry Medvedev.

headline: JGB Yield Flat; Focus on Tankan, Two-Year Tender
summary: A move out of havens and into riskier assets was countered by caution ahead of the release of the Bank of Japan's business-sentiment report this week.

headline: Anglo Irish's Debt Downgraded
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded Anglo Irish Bank's senior debt by three notches due to expectations the troubled bank would require further government support.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Like Hertz
summary: Dollar Thrifty's board said it continues to prefer Hertz's takeover proposal, valued at $1.53 billion, over Avis's slightly higher offer, mainly because of a built-in breakup fee.

headline: Endesa to Sell Assets to Goldman Funds
summary: Endesa said it has agreed to sell 80% of a bundle of natural gas distribution assets for $1.08 billion to two infrastructure funds managed by Goldman Sachs.

headline: David Miliband Urges Labour Unity
summary: The Labour Party battled over its approach to the budget deficit, while David Miliband issued a rallying cry for the party to unite around his brother.

headline: EU Ends Apple Antitrust Probe
summary: The European Commission dropped its preliminary antitrust probe into Apple's App Store and iPhone restrictions, following the company's change to some policies.

headline: Staffing Sector Gains Bode Well for Jobs Market
summary: There are some signs suggesting the worst has passed for the staffing sector, which may be a clue that upcoming jobs data, and the broader economy, will start showing real improvement.

headline: FDIC Set to Approve Securitization Rule
summary: U.S. banking regulators continued to press forward with new rules governing asset-backed securities, seeking to make banks more accountable given the role securitization has played in a number of bank failures.

headline: IMF Endorses U.K. Fiscal Plan
summary: The IMF said the U.K. government's austerity measures are credible and essential to a sustainable economic recovery.

headline: Audi: The Apex of Gasoline-Powered Cars
summary: The Journal's Dan Neil writes that, soon, "we will see the finest gas-powered automobile in history." And he says, it might be this car: the Audi R8 5.2 FSI Spyder.

headline: Santander, M&T Talks Off Again
summary: Talks between Spain's Banco Santander and M&T Bank of Buffalo, N.Y., have stalled again, people familiar with the matter said, adding that they were now pessimistic about a deal being completed.

headline: Trichet Wants Public Finance Monitor
summary: European Central Bank President Jean-Claude Trichet backed the creation of an advisory panel to monitor public finances in the European Union.

headline: How Does A Reverse Mortgage Work?
summary: A reader wants to use a reverse mortgage to downsize to a smaller home.   June Fletcher offers guidance.

headline: Tracking T. Rex's Growth
summary: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County is working on a unique exhibit showing the growth and development of the Tyrannosaurus rex in three stages -- using bones that were previously thought to belong to completely different dinosaurs.

headline: History Lesson
summary: None

headline: Virgin's Branson Derides Malaysian Conservatism
summary: Virgin Group Ltd. founding Chairman Sir Richard Branson said Malaysia's government needs to become more liberal if the nation is to become a more attractive investment destination.

headline: Kashmir's Weekend Respite
summary: The state government on Sunday relaxed curfew orders in several parts of the troubled province of Jammu & Kashmir, which has experienced months of protests. Some snapshots.

headline: Exporters Lead Tokyo Higher
summary: Japanese shares advanced to lead Asian markets higher Monday, snapping a three-day losing streak. The Nikkei was up 1.4%.

headline: Japan Export Growth Slows
summary: Japanese exports rose in August, due in part to strong demand for autos and steel, marking the ninth straight month of growth.

headline: Indian Army Helps Out
summary: The Indian army has been called in to reconstruct the pedestrian bridge that collapsed last week near the main venue of the Commonwealth Games. Some snapshots.

headline: Euro-Zone Lending Picks Up
summary: Bank lending to euro-zone businesses increased in August following a decline in July, boosting overall lending to the private sector.

headline: Lagarde Upbeat on French Growth
summary: The French economy is expected to increase 2.5% in 2012, after expanding at least 1.5% in 2010 and 2% in 2011, as it continues to recover from the economic crisis, said French Finance Minister Christine Lagarde.

headline: China Targets Land Hoarding
summary: China said companies that haven't started developing land more than a year after acquiring a site at auction are banned from making bids in other auctions, in its latest effort to stabilize the housing market

headline: Yanks 4, Red Sox 3
summary: Brett Gardner scores on a walk-off walk to give the Yankees a win in 10 innings.

headline: Commonwealth Games Head Sees Progress
summary: The head of the Commonwealth Games said a lot of work has been done in recent days to get facilities ready but much work remains to be done.

headline: Russian President Visits China
summary: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev is visiting China to meet government leaders, with energy cooperation high on the agenda for even closer ties with the world's second-largest economy.

headline: After One Failure, a Dream Ends
summary: Steve Jonsson aspired to be a banker ever since college. After the collapse of Flagship National Bank, which he founded in 1999, he considers himself a "marked person" in the industry.

headline: Edward Lazear: How to Grow Out of the Deficit
summary: Limiting spending increases to inflation minus 1% would balance the budget in less than a decade.

headline: O'Grady: Weekend at Fidel's
summary: Jeffrey Goldberg is not the first American journalist to cuddle up to Castro.

headline: Strangely, a Printed Book Seeks Its Nook
summary: It is heartening to know that Peter Funt believes that the "local-is-better ethos" will lead to a resurgence in indie bookstores, just as many in the publishing industry are saying the printed word's last rites ("The Internet Might Save Main Street," op-ed, Sept. 20).

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: North Korea Heir Adds Second Post
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Il took further steps to set up his son Kim Jong Eun as his preferred successor, naming him to key political posts. The question now is whether he can carry it off.

headline: Facelift for Doctor's Alma Mater
summary: Roy Vagelos, former chairman and chief executive of Merck & Co. and his wife, Diana, will announce a $50 million donation to Columbia University Medical Center.

headline: 'Social Network' Goes to Harvard
summary: It's unusual that film premieres have their after-parties in such perfect locations as "The Social Network," taking over the Harvard Club on 44th Street.

headline: Shades of McQueen
summary: In the battle for sunglass coolness, Persol shades stand alone. Not just because they ooze Italian sophistication, but rather for their close connection to American icon Steve McQueen.

headline: China, Russia Boost Energy Ties
summary: China and Russia signed a string of economic and political cooperation deals, although finalization of a long-awaited gas-supply pact remained out of reach.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Tomatoes Under the Hammer
summary: So what if an heirloom-tomato charity auction at Sotheby's sounded sort of gimmicky? I felt I had to be there Thursday night.

headline: Investment Banking in China Becomes a Locals' Game
summary: Investment banking, like so many sectors in China, seems to be going the way of the local players. There shouldn't be too much hand-wringing over this back in New York and London.

headline: Liberty Mutual Leads IPO Docket
summary: A half-dozen new stock-market listings from companies based in the U.S., China and Germany should hit U.S. markets this week. Liberty Mutual's IPO could be the largest U.S. offering so far this year.

headline: Dagong Fires Back at SEC
summary: Chinese rating firm Dagong called the SEC's recent denial of its application to be an officially recognized bond rater in the U.S. discriminatory and said it is considering taking legal action.

headline: Lukoil Buys Back Conoco's Shares
summary: Russian oil company Lukoil Holdings said it used an option to buy back 5% of its own shares from U.S. oil major ConocoPhillips for $2.38 billion.

headline: The Post Office Hustle
summary: Another rate increase and more wage hikes.

headline: I'm OK, You're Not OK
summary: When it comes to video cord-cutting, TV executives are moving out of the denial stage. They are now claiming it is someone else's problem.

headline: UniCredit Considers Split Role
summary: Following the resignation of CEO Alessandro Profumo, UniCredit's board is expected to discuss the bank's governance structure this week, including the possibility of a duo of top executives.

headline: Growth in U.K. Financial Sector
summary: Activity in the U.K.'s financial-services sector grew at the fastest rate since June 2007 in the third quarter, but companies are less optimistic about the months ahead than they were in June.

headline: Managing Water as Scarcity Looms
summary: Jean-Louis Chaussade, CEO of Suez Environnement, sees the world in terms of water: The map is becoming arid, and full of opportunity.

headline: The Profit Motive at Battelle
summary: At Battelle Memorial Institute, the goal isn't to just come up with innovations. The goal is to come up with innovations that lead to profit-making products.

headline: Pastor Pledges to Fight Allegations
summary: The leader of one of the nation's most influential black mega-churches pledged to fight accusations that he had coerced four young male followers into homosexual relationships.

headline: Copper Nears Two-Year High
summary: Copper futures are testing their two-year high on the back of gains in U.S. orders for some types of durable goods.

headline: A 'Kinderdealer' Spurs German Debate
summary: The tale of a refugee boy suspected of dealing heroin in the city's subway system has shocked residents of Germany's capital and fanned broader debates on how the country deals both with immigrants and juvenile justice.

headline: What Else Can You Do at 1976 Prices?
summary: I find it inconceivable that, given the theme of your editorial "Tax Wars" (Sept. 11), you failed to mention of one of the most insidious aspects of our current tax code which is the $3,000 ceiling on capital losses carried over to the front of IRS form 1040. It, like the alternative minimum tax, has become a hidden tax.

headline: Rufus Phillips: Curb Corruption or Lose the War
summary: Association with the CIA has given some Afghan officials a sense of impunity, which threatens Gen. Petraeus's hearts-and-minds effort.

headline: 2010 Technology Innovation Awards
summary: Among the winners: computer screens that can bend, adjustable eyeglasses, a low-cost genetic test, an online marketplace for receivables and a new way to battle malware.

headline: House Lashes Out at China Over Yuan
summary: The House passed legislation to penalize China's foreign-exchange practices, sending a powerful warning to Beijing but risking a response that could harm U.S. companies and consumers.

headline: Why Kant We Get Along on This One?
summary: Roger Scruton's suggestion ("Memo to Hawking: There's Still Room for God," op-ed, Sept. 24) that Stephen Hawking's views on the origin of the universe or "multiverse" are really not fundamentally different from Immanuel Kant's views raises an obvious question: Kant we have it both ways?

headline: Exit Deal Surpasses $2 Million
summary: HSBC's departing CEO, Michael Geoghegan, will leave the U.K. lender with $2.25 million in exit pay.

headline: What Happens Under Pressure
summary: Paul Sullivan, in "Clutch," and Sian Beilock, in "Choke," examine why some of us routinely fail under pressure. Both authors give suggestions for what we can all do to get through a make-or-break moment with a better chance of success. Philip Delves Broughton reviews.

headline: Mirae Brings Emerging-Market Funds to U.S.
summary: Mirae Asset Global Investments, one of the world's largest emerging-market investment managers, plans to launch its first mutual funds for U.S. investors on Monday.

headline: Crovitz: Iran's Ahmadinejad, Information Pariah
summary: When a dictator's lies are so easily unmasked, can his threats be ignored?

headline: Regulators Sue Juice Maker POM
summary: The FTC sued POM Wonderful, maker of a popular pomegranate juice, alleging unsubstantiated health claims.

headline: Stadium's Club Is a Football Throwback
summary: The most exclusive part of New Meadowlands Stadium is a dark, wood-paneled lounge that's a throwback to the first half of the 20th century.

headline: White House Seeks Better Wiretap Law
summary: The Obama administration wants a more airtight eavesdropping law that would help law enforcement conduct real-time snooping when people use social-networking sites and other communications technologies.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Probe Karzai Brother
summary: Federal prosecutors in New York have opened a criminal probe of one of Afghan President Hamid Karzai's brothers, raising the stakes in Washington's sometimes-contentious dealings with the Karzai government.

headline: Settlement Freeze in West Bank Ends
summary: There were no signs of a resolution to a settlement dispute that threatens to undermine the newly restarted Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, as Jewish settlers marked the last day of Israel's construction moratorium.

headline: The Turks and Others Should Face History
summary: Regarding your editorial "Barbara Boxer (D., Armenia)" (Sept. 20), the description of those attempting to rectify the Turks' denial of a historical fact as a "tribal Caucasian obsession" is a slap in the faces of the 1.5 million Armenians who died in the genocide.

headline: New Song for Milford Plaza Hotel
summary: One of the city's leading real-estate families is close to a deal to sell its shuttered Milford Plaza Hotel to a partnership led by private-equity firm Rockpoint Group for about $200 million.

headline: Ultra-Modern Brussels Penthouse
summary: Located in the heart of the European capital, this residence has four bedrooms and three bathrooms, with a terrace overlooking Leopold Park.

headline: Using Malpractice Claims to Head Off Mistakes
summary: By analyzing claims in malpractice cases, medical providers are developing programs to correct breakdowns in care that led to missed, delayed or incorrect diagnoses.

headline: Slow Start for SAP's Web-Based Software
summary: Business software as a Web-based service has been heavily promoted by  vendors, but some companies in Europe and the U.K. have been reluctant to adopt the services.

headline: Democrats Face Skeptics in Rural Areas
summary: Congress gets lower approval ratings among rural voters, and that has posed a challenge for Democratic House candidates.

headline: A Foot-Friendly Fourth Remains Elusive
summary: Seven years after Park Slope's Fourth Avenue was rezoned to spur more housing, the goal of a bustling, pedestrian-friendly Park Avenue for Brooklyn remains elusive.

headline: Chinese on Menu for Elementary Kids
summary: More New York elementary schools have begun offering -- even requiring -- the study of Mandarin, spurred by separate pushes by the U.S. and Chinese governments.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Elizabeth Powers on making it in the global economy.

headline: Kim Elevates Son
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Il appointed his third son as a four-star general, the biggest sign yet the family is attempting another father-to-son power transfer.

headline: A Genetic Test for Prospective Parents
summary: The Bronze award in The Wall Street Journal's 2010 Technology Innovation Awards goes to Counsyl for its simple, low-cost test to detect genes in prospective parents that could cause hereditary diseases in their children.

headline: FDIC Delays on 'Next Lehman' Rule
summary: The FDIC delayed action on a rule governing how large financial firms would be treated in the event of another Lehman Brothers-like failure, after government officials said more time was needed to review the proposal.

headline: An Oasis Outside Kandahar
summary: Mahmood Karzai, a brother of Afghan President Hamid Karzai, is the subject of a criminal corruption probe by federal prosecutors in New York. His marquee business project is a housing development on the outskirts of Kandahar.

headline: Banks Keep Failing, No End in Sight
summary: The largest number of bank failures in nearly 20 years has eliminated jobs, accelerated a drought in lending and left the industry's survivors with more power to squeeze customers.

headline: In China, Musicians for the Modern Era
summary: They live mostly on the fringes of big cities and congregate in cyberspace. But so far, the Chinese government has largely left these 'nonconformists' alone.
